title.value: S WEET: Weakly Supervised Person Name Extraction for Fighting Human Trafficking
title.justification: This is the exact title of the paper provided by the user.
title.quote: S WEET: Weakly Supervised Person Name Extraction for Fighting Human Trafficking

extractions.description: This paper presents S WEET, a weak supervision methodology to extract person names from noisy escort ads in the human trafficking domain, leveraging a combination of rule-based and language model-based labeling functions which are aggregated by an HMM-based method. The paper also introduces HTG EN, a synthetic dataset of escort ads generated using ChatGPT.

type.justification: The paper performs experimental evaluations, providing results and comparisons with other methods on various datasets including HTNAME and HTGEN.
type.quote: The experimental evaluations show that S WEET achieves SOTA results on the HTNAME dataset with an F1 score of 0.87, outperforming the previous SOTA by 9% while also generalizing better to CoNLL2003 and WNUT2017 datasets.

name.justification: The paper focuses on Named Entity Recognition, a core task within Natural Language Processing.
name.quote: Named Entity Recognition (NER) is the task of identifying elements in the text that correspond to high-level categories like PERSON, ORGANIZATION, LOCATION, DATES, and other concrete concepts that can be explicitly named.

name.justification: The primary task addressed by the research is Named Entity Recognition, specifically for person names in noisy and adversarial text data from escort ads.
name.quote: Hence, efficient entity extractors must extract accurate and relevant information from ad text.

name.justification: The problem tackled in the research involves extracting specific entities (person names) from text, which is a sub-field of Information Extraction.
name.quote: In this paper, the focus is on human names because they are most associated with an HT victim and names are the most common entity type to appear in escort ads.

name.justification: S WEET is the primary method proposed in the paper for extracting person names using weak supervision.
name.quote: In this work, we propose a weak supervision pipeline S WEET: Supervise Weakly for Entity Extraction to fight Trafficking for extracting person names from noisy escort advertisements.

is_contributed.justification: S WEET is the novel contribution of the paper, designed specifically for this task.
is_contributed.quote: We study the problem of name extraction from noisy text through the novel lens of weak supervision and propose a new method.

is_executed.justification: The methodology section details the implementation and execution of S WEET, involving multiple language models and rule-based functions.
is_executed.quote: The proposed weak supervision pipeline in S WEET consists of 2 main types of LFs: Antirules and Fine-tuned Models.

is_compared.justification: S WEET is compared numerically against other models including NEAT, achieving significant improvements in performance.
is_compared.quote: The experimental evaluations show that S WEET achieves SOTA results on the HTNAME dataset with an F1 score of 0.87, outperforming the previous SOTA by 9% while also generalizing better to CoNLL2003 and WNUT2017 datasets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: S WEET is introduced in this paper and does not reference another title.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We propose a weak supervision pipeline S WEET: Supervise Weakly for Entity Extraction.

name.justification: NEAT is referenced as the previous state-of-the-art method for name extraction from escort ads.
name.quote: Traditional extraction methods, such as the embedding-based Flair (Akbik et al., 2018a) and Spacy NLP models...NEAT (Li et al., 2022) stands as the current SOTA name extractor in this domain.

is_contributed.justification: NEAT is not a contribution of this paper but is used for comparison.
is_contributed.quote: NEAT (Li et al., 2022) stands as the current SOTA name extractor in this domain.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not indicate executing the NEAT model, rather it uses the reported results for comparison.
is_executed.quote: NEAT relies on a sample of manually labeled data to provide optimal results. This is a challenge because the relevant datasets for this task are typically curated in-house and not shared publicly due to their sensitive nature.

is_compared.justification: NEAT is compared numerically in the results section and the paper demonstrates that S WEET outperforms it.
is_compared.quote: S WEET achieves SOTA results on the HTNAME dataset with an F1 score of 0.87, outperforming the previous SOTA by 9% while also generalizing better to CoNLL2003 and WNUT2017 datasets.

referenced_paper_title.value: Extracting person names from user generated text: Named-entity recognition for combating human trafficking
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the title of the reference paper for NEAT used in the comparisons.
referenced_paper_title.quote: NEAT (Li et al., 2022) stands as the current SOTA name extractor in this domain.

name.justification: HTG EN is introduced in the paper as a synthetic dataset of escort ads generated using ChatGPT.
name.quote: Furthermore, we also release HTG EN, a synthetically generated dataset of escort advertisements (built using ChatGPT) to facilitate further research within the community.

referenced_paper_title.justification: HTG EN is introduced in this paper and is not referenced from another paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Furthermore, we also release HTG EN, a synthetically generated dataset of escort advertisements (built using ChatGPT) to facilitate further research within the community.

name.justification: HTNAME is utilized in the experimental evaluations and comparisons of the proposed method S WEET.
name.quote: On re-evaluating NEAT on HTNAME, we found an increase in the strict F1 score from the previous results (0.76 from Table 2 in Li et al. (2022) becomes 0.78), and use this stronger performance as the baseline.

referenced_paper_title.value: Extracting person names from user generated text: Named-entity recognition for combating human trafficking
referenced_paper_title.justification: HTNAME is referenced from Li et al. 2022 as part of the datasets used for evaluation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: On re-evaluating NEAT on HTNAME, we found an increase in the strict F1 score from the previous results (0.76 from Table 2 in Li et al. (2022) becomes 0.78), and use this stronger performance as the baseline.

name.justification: CoNLL2003 is used for training and evaluating language models involved in the study.
name.quote: CoNLL2003(Tjong Kim Sang and De Meulder, 2003) is a very popular baseline for evaluating the performance of different NLP systems and algorithms.

referenced_paper_title.value: Introduction to the CoNLL-2003 shared task: Language-independent named entity recognition
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references the CoNLL-2003 shared task for using the CoNLL2003 dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: CoNLL2003(Tjong Kim Sang and De Meulder, 2003) is a very popular baseline for evaluating the performance of different NLP systems and algorithms.

name.justification: WNUT2017 is used as one of the evaluation datasets to test the generalization ability of the proposed method.
name.quote: WNUT2017(Derczynski et al., 2017) consists of user-generated text and contains many examples of informal language, abbreviations, misspellings, and other noisy characteristics.

referenced_paper_title.value: Results of the WNUT2017 shared task on novel and emerging entity recognition
referenced_paper_title.justification: The WNUT2017 dataset is referenced from the WNUT shared task paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: WNUT2017(Derczynski et al., 2017) consists of user-generated text and contains many examples of informal language, abbreviations, misspellings, and other noisy characteristics.

name.justification: Tweebank is used as an additional evaluation dataset in the experiments.
name.quote: Tweebank(Jiang et al., 2022) was developed to address the challenges of analyzing social media data.

referenced_paper_title.value: Annotating the Tweebank Corpus on Named Entity Recognition and Building NLP Models for Social Media Analysis
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Tweebank dataset is referenced for named entity annotation tasks.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Tweebank(Jiang et al., 2022) was developed to address the challenges of analyzing social media data.

name.justification: The paper uses Skweak as the weak-supervision framework for label aggregation and learning.
name.quote: Skweak (Lison et al., 2021) is a Python-based weak supervision framework made specifically for NER tasks.

referenced_paper_title.value: skweak: Weak supervision made easy for NLP
referenced_paper_title.justification: The Skweak framework is referenced from Lison et al. (2021).
referenced_paper_title.quote: Skweak (Lison et al., 2021) is a Python-based weak supervision framework made specifically for NER tasks.

name.justification: Snorkel is mentioned as an alternative weak supervision framework, but Skweak is chosen due to its better suitability for NER tasks.
name.quote: These make Skweak a better choice compared to other weak label aggregators such as Snorkel (Ratner et al., 2016).

referenced_paper_title.value: Data programming: Creating large training sets, quickly
referenced_paper_title.justification: Snorkel is referenced from the paper by Ratner et al., 2016 discussing data programming.
referenced_paper_title.quote: These make Skweak a better choice compared to other weak label aggregators such as Snorkel (Ratner et al., 2016).

name.justification: Spacy is used within the Skweak framework and is also mentioned for its named entity recognition models.
name.quote: Skweak (Lison et al., 2021) is a Python-based weak supervision framework made specifically for NER tasks. It works together with the Spacy library (Honnibal et al., 2020).

referenced_paper_title.value: spaCy: Industrial-strength Natural Language Processing in Python
referenced_paper_title.justification: Spacy is referenced for its role within the Skweak framework for NER tasks.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Skweak (Lison et al., 2021) is a Python-based weak supervision framework made specifically for NER tasks. It works together with the Spacy library (Honnibal et al., 2020).

name.justification: ChatGPT is used for generating the HTGEN dataset and for labeling the HTU NSUP dataset in the methodology.
name.quote: We also introduce HTG EN, a synthetically generated dataset of escort ads which, unlike the real-world datasets used in papers in this domain, can be published for further research and helps with reproducibility.

referenced_paper_title.justification: ChatGPT is a widely known model developed by OpenAI and the quote references its usage rather than an external paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We also introduce HTG EN, a synthetically generated dataset of escort ads which, unlike the real-world datasets used in papers in this domain, can be published for further research and helps with reproducibility.

name.justification: RoBERTa is one of the language models fine-tuned and used as a labeling function in the S WEET method.
name.quote: Base versions of RoBERTa (Liu et al., 2019) and DeBERTa-v3 (He et al., 2021) for the task of Named Entity Recognition on six different datasets, namely: the train splits of CoNLL2003, WNUT2017, Few-NERD-L1, WikiNER-en, a domain dataset labelled by ChatGPT called HTU NSUP, and a domain dataset generated and labelled by ChatGPT called HTG EN.

referenced_paper_title.value: RoBERTa: A Robustly Optimized BERT Pretraining Approach
referenced_paper_title.justification: The RoBERTa model is referenced from the paper by Liu et al., 2019.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Base versions of RoBERTa (Liu et al., 2019) and DeBERTa-v3 (He et al., 2021) for the task of Named Entity Recognition on six different datasets, namely: the train splits of CoNLL2003, WNUT2017, Few-NERD-L1, WikiNER-en, a domain dataset labelled by ChatGPT called HTU NSUP, and a domain dataset generated and labelled by ChatGPT called HTG EN.

name.justification: DeBERTa is one of the language models fine-tuned and used as a labeling function in the S WEET method.
name.quote: Base versions of RoBERTa (Liu et al., 2019) and DeBERTa-v3 (He et al., 2021) for the task of Named Entity Recognition on six different datasets, namely: the train splits of CoNLL2003, WNUT2017, Few-NERD-L1, WikiNER-en, a domain dataset labelled by ChatGPT called HTU NSUP, and a domain dataset generated and labelled by ChatGPT called HTG EN.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The DeBERTa model is referenced from the paper by He et al., 2021.
